comments:
This class is a general introduction to the scientific study of language structure,
history, and use. Topics include notions of grammar; written versus spoken (and signed)
language; the structure of sounds, words, sentences, and meanings; language in culture
and society; language change over time; language acquisition and processing; comparison
with non-human communication systems.
Many found the material covered in the course interesting, but lectures a bit
boring. Many also cited the lack of a textbook as a bit troublesome.
In general, students felt that Professor Liberman was unable to stimulate the
interest of the class, though some students felt that he was “approachable” and “funny.”
Some students also mentioned that lectures would sometimes get off-topic. However, the
majority of students found his online lecture notes to be extremely helpful.
Overall, most students felt that obtaining a good grade in this class was not too
difficult.
